com.cubeia.firebase.api.server.conf
Interface Configurable

All Known Subinterfaces:
JDBCLoginConfig
public interface Configurable

This is the root interface to extend for configuration interfaces. Configurable interfaces will be fulfilled by the configuration system based on configuration sources which can be flat files, databases or network sources.

The rules for configurable interfaces are dependent on underlying implementation, but in short these steps will happen:

  1. The interface is associated with one or more config sources.
  2. All "get", "is", "do", "has" methods are matched by rules to property names (see below)
  3. Default values are set using annotations
  4. An anonymous object implementing the interface is returned which returns values from the config sources as calculated in previous steps
Property Resolution: Method names are matched to property names by converting the method name, like so:

  1. Method "prefix" ("get", "is", "do", "has") is removed.
  2. The character immediately following the prefix is converted to lower case.
  3. All other upper case characters are converted to lower case and prefixed with a hyphen.
For example, the method "getClassName" will match the property "class-name", the method "isAlone" the property "alone" etc. A special case is if a prefix is not found, in which case only conversion rule #3 above is used, eg. method "googleMe" will match "google-me".

Property names can be overridden with a method annotation.

Inheritance: Each interface can be mapped to an optional namespace via a root annotation. This is a logical string used to separate properties. Namespaces are resolved from left to right and exhibits relations on matching strings, ie. namespace "com.company" is a child namespace to "com", "com.busted" is a parent namespace to "com.busted.hard" etc.

A configurable interface mapped to a namespace will force the properties to to be resolved in relation to the namespace. Some examples:

  • Namespace "node.client" and method "getNodeClass" resolves to "node.client.node-class".
  • Namespace "service" and method "doAutoStart" resolves to "service.auto-start".
  • Namespace <null> and method "sayHello" resolves to "say-hello".
Both the interface and the methods can be marked using their annotations (Configurated and Property respectively) as allowing inheritance. This will allow the system to resolve properties from their logical parent namespace if not found in the declared namespace. For example, if an interface is mapped to "node.client" and has a method "getNodeClass" and is marked to allow inheritance, the system will first search for property "node.client.node-class" and if it is not found it will recurse "backwards" in the namespace and search for "node.node-class" and ultimately "node-class". This allows the configuration to supply default values in parent namespaces and specific overriding values in child namespaces.

Fallback: If a property is not found during resolution a fall back to another property can be made. This is indicated by the "fallback" member of the Property annotation. If a fallback is declared, the ordinary property name is resolved first, including inheritance, after which the fallback name is tried, also using inheritance. This way a configuration method can default to the value of another property if not specificly specified.

If an interface is marked with inheritance rules it can still be overridden for single methods.

All method on a configurable interface should declared that they throw a configuration exception to allow the subsystem to pass up errors to the calling code.

Author:
lars.j.nilsson
